title: being pregnant during the service?

content: Being in a family way is permitted in the service, but there are some caveats that go with it. Someone wanting to really push the issue can get into the matters of time and place of incuring said condition, some of which may be reason for admin action. Then if you are married or not can get involved to varying degrees, such as if your partner is also military and deployed when you enter into said state, or if the partner believes he is not the cause of said condition and gets testing that validates his claim. In short, yes you may, if you so desire, enter into a state gestation, but there is always more to it than just the yes or no answer. Now then, that settled, there are the other related issues. People in the military tend to be of extreme views, and a person getting in a family way right before deployment will tend to result in unfavorable views by members of ones unit, which may or may not be expressed, and if expressed may or may not be in the vicinety of the impregnated individual. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: BTDT X 2 (+ 1 kid during a break in service). I spent 27 years in, so don't tell me or any of the other career-military moms that we are/were "skating by." That's offensive in the extreme. There are those who abuse the system, just as there are men who abuse the system in different ways. The majority of men AND women do NOT abuse the system and contribute more than their share every day - and you all know it!
reply: BTDT X 2 (+ 1 kid during a break in service). I spent 27 years in, so don't tell me or any of the other career-military moms that we are/were "skating by." That's offensive in the extreme. content: I hope the warnings are not directed at me. However, if my post is in part or completely responsible for the warning issued in this thread I would like to apologize at this time and attempt to clarify my earlier statements. I did not mean to infer that females in the service deliberately attempt to get themselves into a family way, nor do I believe that such is the case over all. I ment to state that some people in the military take extreme views and that the issue of a woman being with child was viewed by some members as a dodge. I know that the majority of female members of the military do not use it in such a way. However, much like the news when it comes to the police, we hear about the bad apples in the group, and some women do such things. Likewise some male members have dodged their service obligations in various ways as well. I hope this clarifies any confussion from my earlier post. I did not wish, nor intend to infer that the majority of women attempt to skirt their obligations, I only ment to state that a stereotype exist that portrayes that situation. To anyone I may have offended by my lack of clarity, I apologise. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

title: being pregnant during the service?

content: Indeed there are some bad apples in the group. There are women who use pregnancy to get out of a tour or any job they don't like. However, for those who suggest any kind of punishment for such women, it seems to me the guy who gets them in that shape should also be held accountable. Having said that, there are many women and men who manage both a military career and raising a family very well. But you do have to consider the consequences. I was gone when my younger son started T-Ball, when he learned to ride a bike, and when he had the chicken pox. I never got to see my older son participate in a swimming competition because I was always on duty. My younger son had to cope with his father having emergency surgery while I was TDY. There will absolutely be times when your military duty takes precedence over the needs of your family. Many parents try to compensate by giving their kids everything they want, which usually leads to having kids who have an overdeveloped sense of entitlement. And it absolutely takes both parents, whether both are in the service or not, to make it work.
reply: Indeed there are some bad apples in the group. There are women who use pregnancy to get out of a tour or any job they don't like. However, for those who suggest any kind of punishment for such women, it seems to me the guy who gets them in that shape should also be held accountable. I was gone when my younger son started T-Ball, when he learned to ride a bike, and when he had the chicken pox. I never got to see my older son participate in a swimming competition because I was always on duty. My younger son had to cope with his father having emergency surgery while I was TDY. There will absolutely be times when your military duty takes precedence over the needs of your family. Many parents try to compensate by giving their kids everything they want, which usually leads to having kids who have an overdeveloped sense of entitlement. And it absolutely takes both parents, whether both are in the service or not, to make it work.

content: Down m551, down! Don't you know we have sensitivity training in the military these days? It was part of petty officer indoctrination, where I was trained that no matter what I say someone, somewhere may potentially be offended and that I should be considerate of their feelings and offer a clarification and apology for misunderstandings thus incured. I'll have to find my notebook from it and scan a few pages, I got some nice sketches in it of my thoughts at the time on the subject of the class... Jonsey36, the doc on my boat had a good policy, no liberty without a minimum of signing for and recieving 3 jimmy caps. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

title: being pregnant during the service?

content: Down m551, down! Don't you know we have sensitivity training in the military these days? It was part of petty officer indoctrination, where I was trained that no matter what I say someone, somewhere may potentially be offended and that I should be considerate of their feelings and offer a clarification and apology for misunderstandings thus incured. I'll have to find my notebook from it and scan a few pages, I got some nice sketches in it of my thoughts at the time on the subject of the class... Jonsey36, the doc on my boat had a good policy, no liberty without a minimum of signing for and recieving 3 jimmy caps. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: Mind you all I am out of the navy these days, but the only way I will ever be pregnant will be by association. I passed a kidney stone once, I'll decline the option of passing something that is measured in inches and pounds. Grams and milimeters was bad enough. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.
